content: Added "write answer" to stub generator so that the initial default code shows the syntax for debugging and outputting the answer.

Added a new test case and a new validator ("Check your absolute value") where the absolute value of f(n) gets greater than 2 earlier than its real part and/or its imaginary part becoming greater than 2. The result will be off by 1 if the absolute value is not defined correctly in a player's code (which was my case but I still passed with 100%).

There's one thing that IMHO may not be obvious from the task description: 
what should be the answer if the sequence does *not* diverge?

One (including me) could argue we need 0/1 (and not m) iterations to declare that the sequence value is not greater than 2.

I would suggest making it more explicit.

The parsing asymmetry between real and imaginary part is very disturbing to me.

Would it bother anyone if I edited out the spaces between the imaginary part's absolute value and its sign?
I was attempting this in ruby, and I also noticed that. I made a hasty workaround of splitting by space and then feeding it into the Complex constructor.

I thought the last line of the goal made it clear, either you output how many iterations it took to get a result with an absolute value greater than 2 or you output m, whichever is less. I thought I included a good number of test cases with useful names as well.

Can you explain how you can use 0 or 1 iteration to determine that the value is in the set? It's not a matter of knowing if its absolute value is less than 2, it's a matter of knowing if repeated iterations of the equation will ever produce a value with an absolute value greater than 2.

One can show that, if |c| is less than or equal to 1/4, then c is in the set. This can be used to determine if c is in the set without any iteration.

However, I am aware of only one result that tells you whether c is in the set given only f(n), and it is the one you give in the puzzle's statement (that is,|f(n)| > 2 => c not in the set).

Do you think that modifying the last line to this will clear up confusion:

For this puzzle, you must return the number of iterations necessary for the absolute value of f(n) to exceed 2 or the maximum number of iterations [[m]], whichever is less.
In case of no element out fo the first ***m elements*** satisfies this equation, you have the (hopefully right) answer after checking ***m elements*** actually.
However you still have the same answer as after checking first 0 elements. I don't say either line is correct but both have some reasoning and it would be great to make it more explicit.

If you want to remove the space to the right of the sign I'd also want to see the space on the other side of the sign removed.

I like it the way it is but I'd be willing to defer to your judgement if you feel strongly about it.

I don't care at all about the space before the sign. My view is: currently the sign for the real part is interpreted as a sign, and the one for the imaginary part as an operation. That's the asymmetry that disturbs me.

The whole format is just generally the convention used in this field. I agree that the parentheses and spaces have no utility in the context of this question and could all be stripped without losing much other than some input parsing complications.

As suggested in the previous comments, I have removed the spaces surrounding the sign between the real and imaginary parts.

I have also updated the solution accordingly.

In python a simple regex works fine:
m = re.match(
    r'^(-?[0-9.]+)\+?(-?[0-9.]+)$',
    input().strip('()i'))
c = complex(*map(float,m.groups()))

I feel this is becoming my most common post in the puzzle moderation queue, but here it comes again:

Being "simple" doesn't mean it's "an appropriate part of the puzzle".

Since author's argument was "convention used in this field", I went out and checked how "The Fractal Geometry of Nature" (arguably the standard setter) did.

Pretty hard to find some, since the author assumes (a lot more than) proficiency in complex numbers, but there are a few real/imag splits in the "Cantor and Fatou dusts" chapter (chapter 19, p180 in the 1983 edition), and the spacing there is minimal (less than a thin space, to me it just looks like the base inter-letter space. No kerning), no parentheses.

A single monospace space being wider than the two of those hypothetical ones *plus the i*, I sincerely think dropping them was the right choice.

I'll drop the parentheses, update the code, and approve. (yes, for all this bickering, it *is* a nice puzzle!)

(I had no issue with the cutoff definition, but did clarify it a bit just in case. We'll see if more is needed as the first complaints start raining in the forum :-)
Thanks to you and the other commenters for constructive comments and helping get this puzzle into an approvable form.
